I finished my new Wraeththu novel, â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™, just in time for its December release. Itâ€™s fortunate that our printers have such a fast turnaround (one to two days to generate electronic proofs after files are uploaded), because I did cut it really fine. But now itâ€™s been uploaded, prepared and approved, and printed copies are on their way to me, so the book will be ready to go on the release date of 12th December, when weâ€™ll be holding our annual Immanion Press Yule party. The beautiful cover is by Ruby and features Meladriel, one of the main characters.

This book took me far longer to write than Iâ€™d anticipated. Part of this was down to the fact that Danielle Lainton and I have had to take on full responsibility for Megalithica Books, following its managerâ€™s departure from Immanion Press early this year. Iâ€™ve had to do a lot more editing, even though Louise Coquio has come onboard as the senior editor for the non-fiction list. Danni and I completely revamped the Immanion Press web site this year, and also my personal web site, which took a lot of work and effort and time. On top of these extra duties, â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™ insisted on complicating itself. Initially, it was to have been an extended version of â€˜The Emptiness Next Doorâ€™, the story I wrote for the â€˜Para Spectralâ€™ anthology, but I didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d extend it that much. I anticipated that it would be at most a longish novella. However, once I started writing, adding a couple of extra characters, the book took the bit between its teeth and galloped off with no intention of listening to my attempts to order it to slow down, or even stop! In theme, itâ€™s closest to â€˜The Moonshawlâ€™, in that the characters investigate an historical mystery that manifests through paranormal events. But other than that, itâ€™s a very different story. Itâ€™s set in Ferelithia â€“ and those who are familiar with the Wraeththu Mythos will know thatâ€™s where Pellaz met Caeru before he was Tigron. To those who are unfamiliar with the lore, itâ€™s a Wraeththu party town â€“ rather like Ibiza used to be. But while itâ€™s a prosperous, hedonistic place, filled with tourists, few are aware of its dark history. Until the past begins to seep from the soil.

Louise was the main editor for the book, (Wendy Darling did a read through and offered feedback also), and read all the drafts â€“ even a few chapters Iâ€™d send her now and again for feedback. Midway through the book she felt something was missing, and it was at her suggestion I added the character Ulien â€“ a young har targeted by a malevolent har, or entity or ghost â€“ whatever he is! I also gave the town itself a viewpoint â€“ just a short page here and there. I didnâ€™t intend for the story to stretch as much as it did. Other characters demanded to have more of a role â€“ including Caeru himself (which is, I hope, rather a fan pleaser â€“ Caeru having an adventure of his own rather being merely a supporting character of the Aralis dynasty). November arrived and I felt the book wasnâ€™t anywhere near finished. To be honest, I started to panic, calmed only by Louâ€™s assurance all would be well, that the remaining work wasnâ€™t as much as it seemed, and Iâ€™d have plenty of time to see to it. Then suddenly, it was done, all the dangling ends tied neatly. I was exhausted but happy â€“ and most importantly, pleased with the result. So while â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™ often felt horribly like a vampiric child, sucking all the life juice from me, it clearly thrived on the sustenance!

This book isnâ€™t as grim as some of the Wraeththu Mythos Iâ€™ve written over the past couple of years. â€˜Blood, the Phoenix and a Roseâ€™ was gruesome in places and while the endings to the three novellas that comprised it werenâ€™t relentlessly downbeat, they werenâ€™t exactly cheery either. Similarly, some of the stories Iâ€™ve contributed to for various Mythos anthologies have been somewhat bleak â€“ and wistful in tone. â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™, while including its own grisly moments, has more of an upbeat denouement. I suppose the spirit of Ferelithia refused to be kept down for long. I didnâ€™t want to find myself stuck in what seems to be the current trend of fantasy being numbingly miserable and brutal. Inspired by Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead, who wrote and directed â€˜The Endlessâ€™, (now one of my favourite movies), who said in one interview I watched that they prefer happy endings, I decided this book would finish well for every character involvedâ€¦ well, nearly every character. I also took inspiration from Cameron Crowe (fans of his will see why and how if they read this book), and the novelist Diane Setterfield, who always makes sure her readers know how every character ends up â€“ even the future of the cat in â€˜The Thirteenth Taleâ€™! I really like that approach â€“ itâ€™s comfortably satisfying â€“ and I hope other readers feel the same. (Her new novel â€˜Once Upon a Riverâ€™ is superb, by the way. Recommended.) While I doubt Iâ€™ll do this for every novel I write, I have for this one!

â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™ will be launched at the Yule Party, at The Shrewsbury Arms in Stafford on 12th December. Weâ€™re also launching two other titles that day. First is another fiction work, a novella by Tanith Lee entitled â€˜The Heart of the Moonâ€™. This has been published only once before and itâ€™s likely not many Tanith fans will have read it. The story is set in an alternate Ancient Greece and concerns a female warrior being sent to the mysterious Isle of the Moon to attend a religious festival. Intriguing and beautifully written â€“ as all Tanithâ€™s works are â€“ the book also includes another Classics-inspired short story, â€˜The Dry Seasonâ€™, set in an alternate ancient Rome. Again, this piece has had low key prior publication â€“ so hopefully the stories in this book will be like new works for many of Tanithâ€™s fans. It has a cover and interior illustrations by Danielle Lainton â€“ very sumptuous!

The third book weâ€™re launching is a non-fiction title called â€˜Psychic Protectionâ€™ by Bill Duvendack. A lot has been written on this subject before, but Bill brings a fresh new take to it. He begins by suggesting that if you think youâ€™re under psychic attack, youâ€™re probably not, and then explains what natural situations, conditions and illnesses might make you think you need to defend yourself psychically. Once all the obvious explanations are dealt with, he goes on to discuss the phenomenon of vampires in our society â€“ not the blood-sucking kind of myth and fiction but emotional and psychic vampires who can leave people feeling drained, even ill. Bill gives advice on how to boost your defences against such types and to strengthen your inner resources generally. This is very helpful even for those who might be sceptical about the idea of needing psychic defence. Such attacks arenâ€™t always the obvious, almost fictional idea, of someone sending out â€˜evilâ€™ thoughts deliberately, or â€“ as in books and movies â€“ causing supernatural events. An interesting read. (Cover by Danielle Lainton.)

As for next year, we have a lot of titles planned, which Iâ€™ll talk about in more depth after the New Year. Iâ€™m editing an anthology of weird landscape stories for NewCon Press, called â€˜Shadow on the Hillsideâ€™. This will be released some time in 2020, and includes stories by such writers as Liz Williams, Freda Warrington, Sarah Singleton, Kari Sperring and Andrew Hook. Iâ€™ll be working on non-fiction projects for Immanion Press but hope to at least begin a new novel. I still have the next Ysobi story planned, which would take him to solve a mystery in Siberia! I started writing it a couple of years ago, but other projects intervened or took precedence. I just have to follow where my muse wants to go â€“ and she can be capricious.

So thatâ€™s all for now. I wish you all a wondrous Yuletide and New Year!

Just a short update on works in progress, since I talked a lot about these projects in my last blog post and thereâ€™s not much to add yet except Iâ€™m working hard on them.

Iâ€™ve been concentrating on the non-fiction title, â€˜Coming Forth By Dayâ€™, which is based upon a correspondence course in Egyptian Magic I ran some years ago. At first, I planned simply to convert the course material into a book, but soon realised some of it wasnâ€™t really suitable for that and required feedback from a tutor. So I revamped it completely. At the moment, the book concentrates upon the Ennead, the â€˜royal familyâ€™ of Heliopolis. These are the gods of the creation myth for that area â€“ and it seems just about every area of Ancient Egypt had their own take on the gods, changing them considerably in some cases to local preferences. Anyway, the book explores the Ennead and its myths in depth, including both visualisations and rituals for each deity: Atum, Shu, Tefnut, Geb, Nut, Osiris, Isis, Set, Nephthys and Horus, as well as for the later generationâ€™s offspring and consorts. The book also includes an overview of Egyptian magic and techniques. Iâ€™m about two thirds of the way through writing the chapters, and hope to bring the book out in the summer.

As there is so much material, I decided to break the project down into at least two volumes, maybe three. The second book will focus on gods and goddesses beyond the Heliopolitan dynasty of divine beings. Iâ€™ve not included any of the feline or leonine goddesses (except for Tefnut whoâ€™s intrinsic to the Ennead), as Louise Coquio and I will be writing a revised, expanded edition of â€˜Bast and Sekhmet: Eyes of Raâ€™ once Iâ€™ve finished work on â€˜Coming Forth by Dayâ€™. â€˜Bast and Sekhmetâ€™ was first published in 1999, and as with the â€˜Egyptian Birth Signsâ€™ book I co-wrote with Graham Phillips about the same time, Louise and I now think that itâ€™s time for a new edition. The original is 20 years old and needs a little reshaping to make it relevant to a modern audience. There have also been new discoveries in archaeology, which Lou and I feel should now be included. Thereâ€™s information about some of the feline-related deities out there nowadays that wasnâ€™t around when we wrote the original.

Iâ€™ve also been working on my new novel, â€˜Breathe, my Shadowâ€™, which is at around 160 pages. However, I want to finish off â€˜Coming Forth By Dayâ€™ before really getting down to working on the fiction project. â€˜Breathe, My Shadowâ€™ is planned for a December release.

As for other Immanion Press books, two which are just about to be released, are â€˜Lord of the Looking Glassâ€™ by Fiona McGavin and â€˜Strindbergâ€™s Ghost Sonata and Other Uncollected Talesâ€™ by Tanith Lee. I spoke about these titles extensively in my last blog post so wonâ€™t repeat myself! Danielle Lainton is currently at work on Fionaâ€™s cover, so itâ€™ll soon be ready for release. John Kaiine produced the cover art for â€˜Strindbergâ€™s Ghost Sonataâ€™, and it also appears on his new Instagram page devoted to his artwork. There are some amazing and intriguing pieces of work on this, some of which he has prints of for sale. The link is https://www.instagram.com/johnkaiineartist/

For the non-fiction list we have â€˜My First Book of Magicâ€™ by Dolores Ashcroft-Nowicki, illustrated by her son Carl Ashcroft, with a cover designed by Danielle Lainton, featuring one of Carlâ€™s drawings. The book explores witchcraft and paganism for a young audience, and will undoubtedly appeal to pagan adults wishing to teach their offspring about the craft. And who better to teach them than Ms Ashcroft-Nowicki? She is a renowned author, practitioner and teacher of the occult sciences and was once a director of studies for The Servants of the Light, an esoteric order formed by W. E. Butler. The book will be released under our Megalithica Books imprint in the summer.

We recently released through Megalithica Books a revised edition of â€˜The Green Stoneâ€™ by Graham Phillips and Martin Keatman, which was responsible for initiating the psychic questing phenomenon in the UK in the 1980s. The book has been long out of print, and difficult to get hold of, with Graham receiving repeated enquiries from readers about if and when it might be available again. Late last year it came to light that not only were second hand copies selling for hundreds of pounds, but that some nefarious outfit had produced a pirate version and was selling it at an inflated price, claiming it was the original. Graham and Martin had not sanctioned this, nor were they receiving any royalties for it. The bootleg version proved difficult to remove from online stores. Second hand book sellers were selling dog-eared copies for a fortune and a dodgy unlicensed publisher was trying to flog â€˜newâ€™ copies of the book, with prices often beyond the reach of an audience who desperately wanted to read it. So for all these reasons Graham and Martin decided they must re-release â€˜The Green Stoneâ€™ themselves, at a fair price and with a wealth of new photographs (around 4 dozen) and a new introduction by Graham. When I first came to read through the book to copy edit it, Iâ€™d forgotten what a great story it is â€“ a really exciting supernatural thriller, but which actually happened. A classic study of the paranormal and a riveting read.

Thatâ€™s all for now. Back to the grindstone! More news soon.

I have a lot planned for this coming year â€“ 2019 is poised to be as busy as 2018 was.

First up â€“ new books Iâ€™m working on.

Iâ€™m currently writing a Wraeththu novel called â€˜Breathe, my Shadowâ€™, which is based on â€˜The Emptiness Next Doorâ€™ a short story I wrote for the â€˜Paraspectralâ€™ anthology last year. As can happen with a short, this piece wanted desperately to be longer. I had hoped to finish it in time for Yule 2018, but because I was so busy with other projects, I wasnâ€™t able to meet that deadline. Iâ€™m not going to specify exactly when this year I hope to publish â€˜Breatheâ€™ but will get to work on it in earnest once I have a few important short stories out of the way. Iâ€™ve been researching a lot for this novel, some of which explores the lore of bees, honey and bee-keeping. This isnâ€™t the main focus of the story but is still important as itâ€™s an interest of one of the characters that has bearing on the plot.

Two of the stories Iâ€™m working on are for the next â€˜Paraâ€™ anthology, which is â€˜Para Mortâ€™, a study of love and death in the world of Wraeththu. The idea for this theme grew from suggestions given to me by Mythos writers Martina BelloviÄovÃ¡ and Maria Leel. I want to go for an outright Gothic feel for this one â€“ doomed love, tragic desire and so on. I did specify in the brief I sent to the Mythos writers that the stories donâ€™t have to be total downers â€“ they can have upbeat endings. Iâ€™ve just finished the first draft of a tale called â€˜The Shade of Qâ€™orlennâ€™ but need to go back through it, adding in scene details and fleshing out some of the interactions between the characters. But that oneâ€™s almost there. Iâ€™ve a choice of two others to write for my second story for the anthology and havenâ€™t yet made a decision about which to go with. The third piece I need to work on before turning to longer projects is my story for â€˜Shadows on the Hillsideâ€™, the weird fiction anthology Iâ€™m editing for NewCon Press. Iâ€™ve an idea for that and have written a few pages. Research for this involves studying old maps and a particular kind of folklore, which I wonâ€™t reveal, as it would be a terrible spoiler for the story. Iâ€™ve also been looking into Middle English and the ancient meanings of some modern words.

One of the most interesting things I discovered yesterday is that English in the Middle Ages had a gender-neutral pronoun â€˜hitâ€™, but also that â€˜heâ€™ could be used instead. So I wasnâ€™t so wrong about using â€˜heâ€™ for Wraeththu as some might claim! Iâ€™m not interested in the fuss around the politics of gender and pronouns, and in fact am uncomfortable with the way extremes of certain politics are infesting â€“ and at worst stifling â€“ creative media nowadays, but I am interested in presenting my androgynous characters as they are â€“ beings who are both male and female, greater than the sum of their parts and endowed with faculties and abilities beyond human experience. I was writing about hara when I was a teenager, (and had met them in my imagination years prior to that), long before modern ideas about identity politics arose. I wrote from the heart, not trying to invest my fantasy world with any one agenda. Wraeththu are what they are â€“ in the way they evolved in my imagination very early in my life. They owe more to mythology and folklore than anything else. And thatâ€™s the nearest Iâ€™ll get to talking about my personal opinions in a public place!

Anyway, back to book news after that little diversion. I aim to get â€˜Para Mortâ€™ out this year, probably with a Yule release and accompanying launch party, which is becoming traditional now. Itâ€™s down to whether the writers can get their work to me in time. Iâ€™ve already had one in from E. S. Wynn so maybe that will spur the others into action! â€˜Shadows on the Hillsideâ€™ should also be released this year. Iâ€™m still waiting on a few stories to come in for that one.

Iâ€™ll also be working on a new non-fiction book this year. Around 15 years ago, I wrote a correspondence course on Egyptian Magic, back when people were more inclined to get involved in correspondence courses. Once this trend tailed off in favour of other forms of learning, the course gathered dust in isolated chambers on my computer. It was only when someone mailed me a couple of years ago to enquire whether that course was still available that it was brought once more to my attention. I didnâ€™t feel I wanted to run the course again, as it requires quite a lot of input from me, discussing the work with students, and reading and responding in depth to their coursework, for which I no longer have time. I offered to let the person have the course as one PDF at a very cut price, for them to work through how they wanted, but I couldnâ€™t act as mentor for it anymore. The person concerned was happy with this, so I transformed all the separate modules into one document to send to them. As I was doing this, I realised the modules could actually be a book. A lot of the material would have to go, because it wouldnâ€™t be suitable for a non-interactive project, but I could add new chapters to replace what Iâ€™d take out.

Iâ€™m writing this book under the very unimaginative â€˜Egyptian Magicâ€™ working title, but intend to come up with something more colourful for the finished work. It wonâ€™t be a quick project by any means, as Iâ€™m having to change the entire structure and come up with a lot of new pathworkings for it. A proportion of what was in the correspondence course was based on material in â€˜Bast and Sekhmet: Eyes of Raâ€™ which I co-wrote with Louise Coquio in the late 90s. I donâ€™t want to rehash that, or just focus upon feline deities, so thereâ€™s a lot to be written for it. At the moment, Iâ€™m looking into the creation myths of Ancient Egypt, and creating workings based upon them. That will be the starting point of the work, after an introductory section discussing the beliefs and practices of the Egyptians and how we can reinterpret them for a modern practice of magic. Again, I intend to get the book out this year, but as with the novel it depends on how much time I get to finish it.

Moving on from my own work, there are plans for several books by other writers. Since Taylor Ellwood parted company with the Megalithica Books imprint, releases have inevitably slowed down somewhat for this list. Even last year, when Taylor was still with us, Megalithica Books published only three titles that werenâ€™t co-written by me. I do have books in the pipeline for the list, but in three cases am waiting for news from the respective writers with whom Iâ€™ve been talking over the past couple of months. I can say for definite that weâ€™ll have a new book from Cornelia Benavidez, expanding her work on the legacy of Victor H Anderson, and thereâ€™s an exciting re-issue of a legendary work thatâ€™s currently in production. Only the fact that a contract with an individual connected with the original work has to be sorted out prevents me from talking more about this book. Sometimes, after a lengthy period of time, itâ€™s difficult for people to get back in touch with those they might have worked with in the past. This is in the case in this situation but as soon as itâ€™s OK to talk about this project the author and I will do so wholeheartedly!

On the fiction side, Iâ€™ll be publishing a book Iâ€™m delighted to have edited. This is â€˜Lord of the Looking Glassâ€™, the short stories of Fiona McGavin. Louise Coquio and I met Fiona way back when we were producing the magazine Visionary Tongue. Fiona provided two stories for us and another one for Jamie Spracklen when he took over custodianship of the magazine. Lou and I both loved Fionaâ€™s stories â€“ they were among the best we received. Later, once I started Immanion Press, I brought out the trilogy â€˜A Dream and a Lieâ€™ by Fiona, her first full-length works. In hindsight, I wish Iâ€™d published this book some years later, after Iâ€™d gained more experience as an editor and publisher. Fionaâ€™s were among the first novels Immanion Press published. Iâ€™d do things a bit differently now, as I know more about what Iâ€™m doing! It was only when I had to contact Fiona again concerning two of her stories, which I wanted to reprint in the Visionary Tongue anthology I edited for NewCon Press, that I asked whether she had enough stories for a book of her own. She did, and â€˜Lord of the Looking Glassâ€™ is the result. These are astounding stories. Fiona, like Tanith Lee, has the gift for taking genre tropes and turning them on their heads. She has a wonderful imagination. I never thought a zombie story could bring tears to my eyes â€“ but â€˜The Contraptionâ€™ did. Fiona tackles vampires, fairy abduction, ghosts, fairy tales, alternate realities, science fiction and post-apocalyptic worlds, but all in a way you wonâ€™t have read before and in a fluid, lyrical style. Iâ€™m happy to report that her story â€˜A Tale from the End of the Worldâ€™ is included in an updated form, (it was always my favourite) as well as a sequel to it, â€˜He May Grow Rootsâ€™. Fiona has intimated she might write a full-length novel set in the world of these two stories, which I really hope she does. I canâ€™t wait to release â€˜Lord of the Looking Glassâ€™ â€“ which should be in late spring â€“ and ask any of you with genre blogs or review sites to help me get Fionaâ€™s work out there. She is a marvellous writer and her work should be better known. I hope to plan a kind of blog tour for her and am happy to send advance copies of the bookâ€™s PDF for review. Please mail me at editorial(at)Immanion-press(dot)com if youâ€™re interested.

Other new fiction publications for 2019 include three more anthologies of Tanith Leeâ€™s stories, which focus upon her uncollected works â€“ stories that appeared briefly in magazines or on web sites and have not yet been included in a printed book. The first of these, â€˜Strindbergâ€™s Ghost Sonata and Other Talesâ€™, is scheduled to appear in April, so that Tanithâ€™s husband John Kaiine can promote it at this yearâ€™s Eastercon. John will also be creating the cover art for the book. For the majority of readers, most of these stories might as well be newly-written as they wonâ€™t have been seen before. Much thanks must go, as has become usual for Tanith collections, to Allison Rich, Tanithâ€™s bibliographer, and also to Jeremy Brett and his staff at the Cushing Library and Archives in Texas, who will provide scans of these often difficult to source stories.

Thatâ€™s about it for news now. The DVD of the film of one my favourite novels, The Little Stranger, is due to arrive today and tonight I intend to watch it with Lou and our respective males. I saw this at the cinema initially and was impressed with what the director did with it. Itâ€™s not very often adaptations are so satisfying!

Itâ€™s been a busy build up to the launch event for new Immanion Press/Megalithica Books publications in December. Iâ€™ve been preparing a number of books for a pre-Yule release, one of which is the much-anticipated SHE: Primal Meetings with the Dark Goddess I co-wrote with author and historian Andrew Collins.

Andy and I got to know one another in 1994, when we were both working on books connected with the Nephilim and the fallen angels. In my case, this was the Grigori trilogy (Stalking Tender Prey, Scenting Hallowed Blood and Stealing Sacred Fire). Andy was working on From the Ashes of Angels, which explored the same mythology from an historical and archaeological point of view. Our mutual friend, Jamie Spracklen, introduced Andy and I to each other, and this resulted in Andy allowing me to use his research material for the Grigori books. Weâ€™ve been firm friends and occasional colleagues ever since.

Iâ€™m really excited about SHE, because it heralds a new direction for my non-fiction imprint, Megalithica Books. As Iâ€™m now running this imprint alone, I intend to venture into new territory with it, steering towards books that investigate the mythologies and beliefs that inspire magical traditions and offer new systems for readers to discover. I donâ€™t want to have my own writing time curtailed too much, so Iâ€™ll most likely be producing fewer books for the list, but every one of them will be a work Iâ€™m personally interested in and intrigued by. Iâ€™m looking for books that explore (or create) rich and vivid magical systems, including pop culture systems that transform fictional characters and worlds into magical entities and environments. Iâ€™m also seeking books on alternative spirituality, such as LHP, and entertaining studies on how to work with particular entities and deities. Iâ€™m after fresh approaches to practices such as meditation, pathworking and ritual, or which reveal personal experiences that are compelling and inspiring. The key words are: imagination, creativity, depth and integrity. If anyone is interested in submitting to the list, please mail me at editorial(at)Immanion-press(dot)com.

Among the first of the new Megalithica Books titles was Zodiac of the Gods, which I released quite quietly a few months ago, under the author name of Eden Crane. This is a reimagining and retitling of a â€˜popularâ€™ book I wrote with Graham Phillips for a mainstream publisherâ€™s New Age list back in the 90s â€“ now itâ€™s very much out of date, written in a style that doesnâ€™t reflect modern culture. Last year, Graham and I revisited the text and changed it to fully represent life as it is today. We also renamed the book to more accurately describe its subject. The original was written for a â€˜womenâ€™s magazine audienceâ€™ with a specific style and content to suit its target demographic at the time it was published. Neither of us want that original still to be available butâ€¦ We had to bring the heavily revamped and revised version out under a joint pseudonym as the original is still available and the publishers concerned refuse to remove it from print or eBook, even given our strong case for this to be done and the fact it barely sells any copies. Big publishers simply donâ€™t like giving books up nowadays â€“ I assume because â€˜just in caseâ€™, and because there are no overheads in keeping eBooks available. They werenâ€™t interested in a new edition from us. I shall refrain from further comment as Iâ€™m sure anyone reading this will intuitively perceive how Graham and I feel about this situation! Zodiac of the Gods has a light-hearted aspect in that it explores the Dendera Zodiac as an alternative to Western Astrology. But in the new version, weâ€™ve significantly expanded the second half of the book, which presents Egyptian magical workings for each month of the year and the deity, or neter, who presides over it. The book is fully illustrated in a completely different style to the original. Itâ€™s sad that the awkwardness about the old version meant we didnâ€™t feel comfortable with doing a big splash release for this much better book under our own names, but now â€“ at least â€“ we want to share its origins.

SHE is the first new title that I can fully promote to launch the new look Megalithica Books. It explores 30 goddesses, some of whom are well-known in Pagan circles, such as Aphrodite, Lilith and Hecate, but others are more obscure but no less intriguing, such as Akhlys, Agrat bat Mahlat and The Cailleach. Even with the more â€˜famousâ€™ goddesses, weâ€™ve delved into their roots to reveal their darker aspects â€“ original facets that have, to some degree, been watered down or removed over time. To us, the original forms are far more fascinating and have more to teach us. We asked friends to contribute a few articles and pathworkings to the book â€“ Deborah Cartwright, Maggie Jennings, Richard Ward and Caroline Wise. SHE includes an essay about each goddess and also a visualisation to meet and interact with her. Not all of those included were goddesses to begin with but have been shaped into deities by Pagans over the years. Some were originally mythological figures â€“ queens or sorceresses â€“ while others were female spirits or entities who were demonised by patriarchal religions. I enjoyed working on this book immensely and learned a lot while researching it. There are illustrations to accompany every goddess, mostly by Danielle Lainton, although I helped out doing a few (there was so much work for one artist!) and weâ€™ve also used one of Rubyâ€™s Sekhmet pictures. The rest were adapted from vintage illustrations. The cover of the paperback features art by Brom, while the hardback has cover art by Danni.

The Collectorâ€™s Edition of SHE, limited to 99 hardback, numbered copies, includes a bonus section, investigating a further three goddesses: Lyssa, Melinoe and Kalma.

Andy and I, as well as Danni and a couple of the contributors who are able to come along, will be at the launch event on 13th December at The Shrewsbury Arms in Stafford. Weâ€™ll give a short talk and readings, and books will be available for purchase, so guests can buy copies of the paperback or hardback and get them signed. Hereâ€™s a link to the Facebook page for it. https://www.facebook.com/events/257889301743853/

Our co-host, Maggie Jennings of Hart Magical Gifts, will have a table at the event, where a selection of her wares will be on sale. Weâ€™re also expecting another local indie publisher, Alchemy Press, to bring some of their books along for sale, including The Alchemy Press Book of Horrors, in which I have a story.

The other Megalithica Books title being launched at the event is Transpiration: Poetry and Storytelling as Our Spiritual Portals by Cornelia Benavidez, which has cover art by Peter Hollinghurst. The first half of the book is autobiographical and gives a fascinating glimpse of the author growing up in America in the 1960s and 1970s, her introduction to alternative spirituality and how it grew in the States during those decades. I was intrigued by Corneliaâ€™s stories from her youth â€“ such colourful characters and vivid memories both bitter and sweet.
